title: Data Science Foundations
text: Free Guide · Updated Feb 2026
crumbs: 1  index.html

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
What You Will Learn
Welcome to Complex Data Insights (CDI) — a structured learning pathway designed to teach real data skills through clear explanations, intentional progression, and reproducible workflows.
This guide focuses entirely on Python, one of the most widely used languages in data science, analytics, machine learning, and scientific computing.
Whether you are new to data work or returning to strengthen your foundations, this guide is built to help you move from raw data to interpretable insight in a clear and disciplined way.
Across this guide, you will learn how to:
Each chapter builds on the previous one.
The progression is intentional.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
Think analytically about data problems

Load, inspect, and structure datasets

Clean and prepare messy data responsibly

Explore patterns through clear visualization

Apply summary statistics correctly

Interpret results with caution and clarity

Build reproducible analytical documents using Quarto
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
How This Guide Is Structured
This guide is organized as a complete workflow:
Data → Preparation → Exploration → Visualization → Interpretation
Rather than isolated notebooks, you are working within a structured Quarto book.
This means:

Code and narrative live together

Results are rendered programmatically

The project is reproducible from start to finish

The entire workflow can be version-controlled

You are not only learning data science.
You are learning how to structure analysis professionally.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
About Figures and Reproducibility
All figures in this guide are generated programmatically during execution.
This ensures that:

Results are reproducible

Visualizations remain consistent

The published book reflects the underlying code

Changes in data automatically update outputs

Reproducibility is not an afterthought.
It is part of the workflow.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
How to Use This Guide
This guide is designed to be:

Self-paced — move forward when concepts are clear

Hands-on — run and modify the code yourself

Structured — follow the workflow in order

Revisitable — return to earlier chapters as needed

If something feels unclear, slow down and revisit the reasoning before moving forward.
Understanding is cumulative.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
Lesson Workflow
Each chapter follows a consistent pattern:

Concept explanation

Guided code examples

Output interpretation

Short exercises

Key takeaways

This structure reduces cognitive overload and keeps learning focused.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
Data and Project Structure
Throughout the guide:

Datasets are stored in a consistent data/ directory

Code execution is integrated into the Quarto book

Outputs are rendered automatically into the final document

This project structure mirrors professional analytical work.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python
text:
About This Guide
This guide follows a human-first, carefully curated approach.
AI tools were used as assistants during drafting and refinement.
All final content has been reviewed and structured intentionally.
crumbs: 2  Welcome to Data Science Foundations in Python

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Recommended Setup
This project is purely Python-based, unless explicitly stated otherwise.
Before we begin exploring data, you need a simple and reliable workspace so you can run code smoothly and follow every lesson without issues.
Use Jupyter Notebook via the Anaconda distribution.
Why this option?
Anaconda installs Python, Jupyter Notebook, and essential data-science libraries in one streamlined setup.
Steps:
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Download Anaconda: https://www.anaconda.com/download

Install it (default settings are fine)

Open Anaconda Navigator

Launch Jupyter Notebook
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Tools Used in This Guide

This guide uses widely adopted open-source tools from the Python data-science ecosystem, including Python, Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, Seaborn, Scikit-learn, and Jupyter. These tools form the foundation of modern data analysis and machine learning workflows.
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Installing Required Libraries
Run the following command in a Jupyter Notebook cell:
!pip install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn

Note:
If you are using Anaconda, these libraries are usually preinstalled.
The command above ensures your environment is up to date.
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Practice Dataset
We will use the Iris dataset in the early lessons of this guide.
You do not need to download it manually at this stage.

A later lesson will generate data/iris.csv automatically

This lesson focuses only on ensuring your environment is ready
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Test Your Setup
You may run the test below after the dataset exists:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv('data/iris.csv')
print(df.head())
Expected output (first rows):
   sepal_length  sepal_width  petal_length  petal_width species
0           5.1          3.5           1.4          0.2  setosa
1           4.9          3.0           1.4          0.2  setosa
2           4.7          3.2           1.3          0.2  setosa
3           4.6          3.1           1.5          0.2  setosa
4           5.0          3.6           1.4          0.2  setosa
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Troubleshooting
If something does not work as expected:

Restart your notebook and try again

Confirm the file path is data/iris.csv

Ensure the data/ folder exists

Re-run the installation command if needed

Setup issues are common. Take your time.
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Exercise

Confirm that Jupyter Notebook opens successfully

Run the library installation command without errors

Verify that you can run a simple Python cell
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment
text:
Summary

You set up a Python-based data analysis environment

You installed essential data science libraries

You verified that your notebook can execute Python code

You prepared your system for working with real datasets
crumbs: 3  Setting Up Your Data Analysis Environment

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Lesson Overview
Every data science project begins with understanding your data. Before you clean it, visualize it, or build any model, you must first know what the dataset contains, how it is structured, and what patterns already exist.
In this lesson, you will load a dataset into Python, inspect its features, explore basic statistics, and create initial visualizations.
By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Load a dataset into a pandas DataFrame

Inspect its structure, shape, and datatypes

Generate summary statistics

Visualize initial feature patterns

Save the dataset for later lessons
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Notebook Initialization

from cdi_viz.theme import cdi_notebook_init, show_and_save_mpl

# Lesson ID drives figure naming (e.g., figures/02_001.png)
cdi_notebook_init(chapter="02", title_x=0)
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Load the Dataset

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris

iris = load_iris()

df = pd.DataFrame(iris.data, columns=iris.feature_names)
df["species"] = pd.Categorical.from_codes(iris.target, iris.target_names)

df.columns = [
    "sepal_length",
    "sepal_width",
    "petal_length",
    "petal_width",
    "species"
]

df.head()








sepal_length
sepal_width
petal_length
petal_width
species

crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Save the Dataset

from pathlib import Path

Path("data").mkdir(exist_ok=True)
df.to_csv("data/iris.csv", index=False)

print("Saved dataset to: data/iris.csv")

Saved dataset to: data/iris.csv
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Inspect Dataset Structure

print("Columns:", df.columns.tolist())
print("Shape:", df.shape)
print("Data types:")
print(df.dtypes)

Columns: ['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width', 'species']
Shape: (150, 5)
Data types:
sepal_length     float64
sepal_width      float64
petal_length     float64
petal_width      float64
species         category
dtype: object
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Histograms of Numeric Features

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df[["sepal_length", "sepal_width", "petal_length", "petal_width"]].hist(
    figsize=(10, 7),
    bins=12
)
plt.suptitle("Iris — Histograms of Numeric Features", y=1.02)
plt.tight_layout()

show_and_save_mpl()




Iris — Histograms of Numeric Features




'figures/02_001.png'
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Scatter Plot

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 5))
ax.scatter(df["sepal_length"], df["petal_length"], alpha=0.7)
ax.set_xlabel("sepal_length")
ax.set_ylabel("petal_length")
ax.grid(True, alpha=0.2)

show_and_save_mpl(fig)




Iris — Sepal Length vs Petal Length




'figures/02_002.png'
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Pairplot by Species

import seaborn as sns

g = sns.pairplot(df, hue="species", corner=True, plot_kws={"alpha": 0.7})
g.fig.suptitle("Iris — Pairplot by Species", y=1.02)

show_and_save_mpl(g.fig)




Iris — Pairplot by Species




'figures/02_003.png'
crumbs: 4  Load and Explore a Dataset

title: Load and Explore a Dataset
text:
Exercise

print("Last 5 rows:")
print(df.tail())

print("\nRows per species:")
print(df["species"].value_counts())

df["petal_area"] = df["petal_length"] * df["petal_width"]

print("\nWith petal_area:")
print(df.head())

147           6.5          3.0           5.2          2.0  virginica
148           6.2          3.4           5.4          2.3  virginica
149           5.9          3.0           5.1          1.8  virginica

versicolor    50
